item.title: Hugo with Staticman Commenting and Subscriptions
item.description: Continuing on from the last post, in which we set-up the BinaryMist blog and business site on Hugo, it was now time to provide some functionality for you to be able to: Leave comments on posts Subscribe to comments on specific blog posts Subscribe to notification by email as new blog posts are published Hugo uses Disqus as it’s default reader commenting system which is a shame, as Disqus is evil, but never fear, I’ve gone ahead and got a commenting system set-up for the Academic theme that won’t abuse you.

item.title: BinaryMist Web Migration
item.description: Synopsis Over the last four to five years I’ve been researching alternative bloggnig platforms in order to move from the Wordpress.com platform I’ve been blogging from. In this post I’ll discuss the migration and consolidation of both the BinaryMist blog, and business site. From: Business Site Full custom Nodejs/Express in Docker container on AWS EC2, behind Cloudflare, using my aws-docker-host. Blog Wordpress.com To: All in one: Business Site with Blog (you’re looking at it now) Hugo with customised Academic theme Staticman for blog commenting (See the bottom of this post for the working example), as we will discuss in the next post, along with sign-up for receiving new post notifications as they are published (See the post list for the working example) Hosted directly from Github (gh-pages) Sitting behind Cloudflare.

item.title: The Cloud Shared Responsibility Model
item.description: This post was taken from the content of the Cloud chapter of Kim’s book Holistic Info-Sec for Web Developers F1 Risks The shared responsibility model is one that many have not grasped or understood well. Let’s look at the responsibilities of the parties. CSP Responsibility The CSP takes care of the infrastructure, not the customer specific configuration of it, and Due to the shear scale of what they are building, are able to build in good security controls, in contrast to the average system administrator, which just does not have the resources or ability to focus on security to the same degree.

item.title: Captcha Considerations
item.description: This post was taken from the content of the Web Applications chapter of Kim’s book Holistic Info-Sec for Web Developers F1 Risks Lack of captchas are a risk, but so are captchas themselves… Let’s look at the problem here? What are we trying to stop with captchas? Bots submitting. What ever it is, whether: Advertising Creating an unfair advantage over real humans Link creation in attempt to increase SEO Malicious code insertion You are more than likely not interested in accepting it.

item.title: Lack of Visibility in Web Applications
item.description: This post was taken from the content of the Web Applications chapter of Kim’s book Holistic Info-Sec for Web Developers F1 Risks I see this as an indirect risk to the asset of web application ownership (That’s the assumption that you will always own your web application). Not being able to introspect your application at any given time or being able to know how the health status is, is not a comfortable place to be in and there is no reason you should be there.
